message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Turner syndrome, which is associated with a webbed neck, excess skin folds, low-set ears, and an increased carrying angle. Inferior rib notching is seen in patients with coarctation of the aorta, which is commonly found in Turner syndrome. Streak ovaries are also common findings in Turner syndrome, and therefore pelvic ultrasound would be the most likely additional finding. Options A and C are associated with Marfan syndrome, while option B is associated with coagulation disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s short and broad neck, bilateral excess skin folds, low-set ears, increased carrying angle, and inferior rib notching suggest Turner Syndrome. Streak ovaries are a common finding in Turner Syndrome. The other options are not associated with Turner Syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including the short and broad neck, excess skin folds, low-set ears, increased carrying angle, and inferior rib notching, suggest Turner syndrome. One of the common findings in patients with Turner syndrome is streak ovaries on pelvic ultrasound. Horseshoe adrenal gland and mutation of FBN1 are not associated with Turner syndrome, while prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time is associated with certain bleeding disorders but not specific to Turner syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has signs consistent with Turner syndrome, including short stature, broad neck, excess skin folds, low-set ears, increased carrying angle, and inferior rib notching. Streak ovaries are commonly seen in Turner syndrome patients. Horseshoe adrenal gland is associated with adrenal hyperplasia, which is not related to Turner syndrome. Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time is associated with clotting disorders, not Turner syndrome. Mutation of FBN1 is associated with Marfan syndrome, which is not related to Turner syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with physical findings of Turner syndrome, including short stature, excess skin folds, low-set ears, and increased carrying angle. Inferior rib notching is also suggestive of Turner syndrome. Streak ovaries on pelvic ultrasound are a common finding in patients with Turner syndrome. Horseshoe adrenal gland is not associated with Turner syndrome. Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time is not a common finding in Turner syndrome. Mutation of FBN1 is associated with Marfan syndrome, which presents with different physical features such as tall stature, long arms and fingers, and aortic dilation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, which is associated with streak ovaries on pelvic ultrasound. Horseshoe adrenal gland is associated with certain genetic syndromes but not specifically associated with Turner syndrome. Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time is associated with bleeding disorders, also not specifically associated with Turner syndrome. Mutation of FBN1 is associated with Marfan syndrome, which can also present with rib notching but does not explain the other findings in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The short and broad neck, bilateral excess skin folds, low-set ears, and increased carrying angle suggest Turner syndrome. Inferior rib notching is a feature of coarctation of the aorta, which is commonly associated with Turner syndrome. Among the options, only streak ovaries on pelvic ultrasound are associated with Turner syndrome. Horseshoe adrenal gland on abdominal CT is not associated with Turner syndrome but can be seen in some cases of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time suggests bleeding disorders, while mutation of FBN1 on genetic testing suggests Marfan syndrome.

Streak ovaries are a common finding in patients with Turner syndrome and can be detected by pelvic ultrasound. Options A, B, and C are not typically associated with Turner syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient shows signs of Turner Syndrome, which is most likely caused by a missing or partially missing X chromosome. Of the options, only streak ovaries on pelvic ultrasound is a common finding in Turner Syndrome. Horseshoe adrenal gland is a rare finding in some types of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, and mutations of FBN1 are associated with Marfan Syndrome, which presents with different physical characteristics. Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time is not specifically associated with Turner Syndrome.
